text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text beginning to the right of and below a large historiated initial. The initial occupies the height of two lines of text, with foliate extensions into the left margin. Text is set in a block below the initial’s vignette.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with decorative flourishes and extensive abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for the frame, crown and sceptre to denote royal authority; the ultramarine background emphasizes the central figure; vermillion red highlights the tunic; green defines the ground plane. Layered application with subtle white lead highlights on armor and flesh. Pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening.

features: Single standing figure placed at the exact center of the roundel
Circular gold frame functioning as a visual focus
Flat blue background to isolate the figure
Green ground line anchoring the figure

decorative_elements: Marginal curling vine-scrolls with stylized leaves
White penwork tracery on blue ground

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill pen outlines with consistent weight, slight variation to suggest drapery folds
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal shading; flat color fields with isolated white highlights on metal and flesh
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling; no attempt at linear perspective; shallow ground plane

content_theme.scene_description: Within a large initial roundel, a crowned king stands full-length facing the viewer. He wears a gold crown and holds a sceptre in his right hand and a globus cruciger in his left. His torso is clad in a red surcoat over chainmail, with a short gold skirt of mail below. A sword hangs at his left hip. He stands on a green ground line against a flat ultramarine field. The gold frame of the initial forms a circular border. Costume details include mail chausses visible on his legs and pointed azure shoes. His expression is solemn, with finely rendered facial features. Secondary decorative elements include white tracery on the blue ground and a curling vine-scroll in the left margin. Symbolic components are the sceptre (justice) and orb (worldly rule). Compositionally, the figure is centered to emphasize his status, with balanced negative space around him. Visual weight is concentrated on the crowned head and regalia objects. The historiated initial integrates with the text by marking the opening of a significant section, guiding the reader’s eye from image to inscription.

secular: King wearing crown, red surcoat over chainmail, holding sceptre and globus cruciger

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness; surface carefully scraped, pumiced and polished
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall very good. Pigments retain brightness; minor flaking of vermillion in the surcoat; slight cockling at the outer margin edge.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf frame
Underdrawing visible in lead white under UV examination
Regular pricking and ruling for text and initial placement

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This historiated initial dates to the mid-13th century and likely originated in a northern French court workshop, reflecting the high value placed on regal imagery in illuminated manuscripts. The use of costly ultramarine and burnished gold leaf indicates a commission by or for a member of the aristocracy, situating the volume within the milieu of princely education or courtly display. Stylistically, the rigid frontal posture and symmetrical composition exhibit continuity with earlier Romanesque traditions, while the nuanced facial modeling and delicate penwork tracery point to emerging Gothic innovations. The collaborative nature of the workshop is evident in the consistent quality of the text’s Gothic textura and the figure’s refined execution, suggesting specialized scribes and illuminators. Iconographically, the sceptre and globus cruciger clearly communicate sovereign authority and the divine sanction of kingship, aligning secular power with sacral overtones. The initial’s role at the opening of a textual section underscores the interplay between word and image as mnemonic and didactic tools. Comparatively, this illumination bears resemblance to the Psalter of Blanche of Castile in its color palette and ornamental motifs, yet it introduces more naturalistic facial types and heightened gold relief work. Thus, the page embodies a transitional moment in manuscript art, marrying traditional hierarchical iconography with the burgeoning naturalism and technical prowess of the Gothic era.
